reviews/4/text: While planning our trip to Aveiro I came across a recommendation of this oyster farm but information was very limited. Since my wife loves oysters, while I usually skip,  I decided to surprise her and noted the name. After strolling through Aveiro for a couple of hours we returned to the car, put the name on the Waze, and to my great surprise shortly arrived to a spot on the water at the outskirts of the village. There was nothing in sight. An old man was sitting in a small car nearby so I approached him. He did not speak a word of English but upon seeing the name in my notebook mimicked to me to wait. He made a phone call and within a few minutes another car arrived. In it was Sandro who politely explained that the place is closed and reservations are usually required. Noting our big disappointment and due to the fact that we were on our way to Porto, he immediately decided to host us. He called Sandra's father who manages the small boat, took us to this beautiful place, asked a lovely young man to show us the farm and finally opened the kitchen for us so we could order the most amazing oyster meal. Even I enjoyed these special oysters which my wife claims were the best she ever had. This private meal in such a beautiful setting, hosted by such wonderful people was the highlight of our Portugal trip.

To visit this museum in Aveiro, it is good to park the car into the underground carpark of the “Forum” and from here you are at walking distance of the museum and the cathedral of Aveiro. The Museum de Aveiro has been installed since the year 1911 in the former “Convent de Jesus of the Dominican Female Order”. This convent, who is one of the oldest in Aveiro, dates back to the second half of the 15th century, and got founded by D. Brites Leitão and D. Mecia Pereira.

Princess Joana, daughter of Afonso V, enters this house in the year 1472 and lives a life of sanctity here, leading to her beatification in the year 1693. The prestige of the convent was thus definitively associated with the presence of Princess Santa Joana and her cult religious.

The Museum of Aveiro presents a visiting circuit with two distinct parts: the monumental route and the permanent exhibition.

On the ground floor of the convent, the tomb of Santa Joana Princes, the Church of Jesus, the cloister, the chapter room and the refectory stand out.

The town is characteristic with its river canals, few km away from the Atlantic coast. There're many gondola tours (motor powered and bigger) which are painted in vivid colors. It cannot be compared to Venice in any way as many others do, and I personally hate such comparisons and tourist platitudes. 
The old town is compact and charming with nice churches, shops, bars, restaurants and pastries shops selling local sweet delicacy - Olos Moles.
Great break for 3-4 hours. Park your car at the Forum Aveiro shopping mall which is in the very center with everything in walking distance.

This is an amazing chapel with a huge local history: every year on the first Sunday in January, locals will fill this area where people go to pay promises that they have made the previous year. Depending on what they promise, they throw a huge giant Cavaca (a kind of cookie) from the top of the chapel and smash them in the ground. The ancient say it bring good luck if you pick and eat the pieces that fall on the floor.
This tradition started during the black plague as way for the rich to give food to the poor with less risk of catching the disease. How? By throwing the food from the top of the chapel away from people that could carry the the lethal plague.

La piccola cappella di Santa Maria, conosciuta anche come Cappella di San Gonçalinho, è un omaggio di devozione al Beato da parte dei pescatori locali e risale al XVII secolo con successive modifiche.

La pianta è insolitamente esagonale e la sobrietà e semplicità delle forme architettoniche alleggerisce la parte alta della cappella.

Il prospetto principale è in pietra locale (ançã) sormontato da un campanile centrale, mentre il portale è fiancheggiato da doppi pilastri e sormontato da trabeazione toscana.

All’interno altari laterali e l'altare maggiore della prima metà del XVIII secolo XVIII, mentre la sagrestia è rivestita con piastrelle bianche e blu come la cupola.

Una piccola e storica testimonianza di fede e devozione

reviews/13/text: I grew up hearing about the "Ría de Aveiro", in the small town of Aveiro, commonly known as the little "Portuguese Venice". Along the Atlantic Coast, the "Ría de Aveiro" - a lagoon and a few shallow canals - runs for 45 kms in lenght, with a width, at its largest point, of 11 kms. The lagoon was formed, in the 16th century, as a result of a sea retreat and, some time later, by the construction of coastal cords which originated the lagoon. The best way to visit the "Ría de Aveiro" is taking a tour, on one of the many traditional boats - the "Moliceiros". These boats were originally conceived for the collection and transport of the "moliço", an acquatic plant used as a fertilizer. They are painted with bright colors and decorated with unique motifs. Ancient salinas, along the lagoon, used to produce "Flor de Sal", a quite expensive and disputed salt variety. Evidently, Venice is too far away, but Aveiro is a magic romantic town and deserves a visit by all those traveling in Northern Portugal! Enjoy!

► Almost every city in Portugal has its typical sweet pastry. Aveiro has the Ovos Moles, an egg yolk with sugar, sourced from an ancient women's monastery. Its shape is obtained by mixing eggs and sugar patiently and is prepared according to traditional knowledge. After the nuns disappeared, the recipe passed from generation to generation and is preserved to this day.
► I thought it would be nice to see how the pastry is made so I signed up on the website in advance.
► The workshop is located on the main street near the main canal.
Our group included our family and group of young and cheerful students visiting Portugal.
The cute guide told us in excellent English about the history of the pastry and made most of it in front of our eyes. She even let us help a little bit.
In the end, we tested one. We didn't really like it: too sweet, lots of filling in thin dough. Well... everyone and his own taste...

reviews/8/text: La Praça Humberto Delgado a été nommée en l’honneur du Général Humberto da Silva Delgado (1906-1965), militaire au sein de la Force aérienne portugaise et homme politique portugais (chef de l'opposition au dictateur António de Oliveira Salazar). Il aurait été assassiné par balle en Espagne par des membres de la police politique portugaise. Ce carrefour giratoire construit au-dessus du canal d’Aveiro (le pont marque en fait la limite entre le canal central et le canal do Côjo) est un point stratégique de la ville d’Aveiro pour les visiteurs en auto car il est situé à proximité des autoroutes (A25/IP5 et N235) ainsi que du centre commercial Forum Aveiro et de son stationnement souterrain. Une grande partie des attractions touristiques de la ville sont situées de part et d’autre du canal. De plus, de très beaux exemples d’édifices Art Nouveau qui font la réputation internationale d’Aveiro pour le Portugal sont facilement visibles depuis le pont de la Praça Humberto Delgado, juste en face, sur la rua Joâo Mendonça, aux nº 24 et 25 (Édifice de la Maison des Ovos Moles), aux nº 11 et 13 (Musée de la Cité) et aux nº 5, 6 et 7 (Édifice de la Coopérative Agricole). C'est aussi depuis ce point d’observation que l’on a la plus belle vue sur l’ancienne capitainerie du port d’Aveiro.

This bridge is just next door to the underground parking of the “Forum”. The bridge contains a set of four bronze statues placed at the four ends of the bridge over the Central Canal, currently known as Praça Humberto Delgado. All of them are full-length, however they have dimensions below the real one.
Each statue represents a traditional figure of the city, two from the working environment, Salineira and Marnoto; and the remaining characteristics of the feast days: the Parceira do Ramo and the Fogueteiro.

Much if the canalside is walkable too though if you prefer that, but the boat cruise is with doing too.

Two beautiful churches side-by-side, connected by a arch. I find difficult to say which one is more beautiful, because they are so different and so outstanding. 
One is dedicated to Saint Anthony of Padua (born in Lisbon) and the other to Saint Francis of Assis. 
The arquitecture is Barroc from XVII and XVIII century and we can find a lot handmade pieces of golden carving and Ancient artistic tiles.
The most outstanding is that every wall, tells a story. Important Franciscan religious symbols are everywhere. I felt a mystical sensation in this place.
reviews/1/text:
Saíamos caminhando em direção do Parque Infante e passamos em frente a esta igreja, na verdade é uma igreja e uma capela num mesmo espaço, grudadas.
Decidimos entrar e tivemos o prazer de sermos recebidos por um senhor, que até agora não sei se era padre ou apenas um apaixonado pela história destas duas igrejas.
Nos levou no passo a passo, primeiro a sacristia depois às naves das duas igrejas e por fim um pequeno museu. Valeu a pena, tudo lindo e com muita histporia
reviews/1/title: Bela e com visita guiada Igreja São Francisco e Capela Santo Antonio
reviews/2/text: 1524年に聖フランシスコ修道会の修道士によって献堂されました。ポルトガル風バロック様式の彫刻やパドヴァの聖アントニオの生涯を描いたアズレージョは特徴的です。
reviews/2/title: アズレージョはパドヴァの聖アントニオの生涯
reviews/3/text: Convento fundado em 1524 em terreno doado por João Nunes e mulher. A arqitectura do conjunto é simples e contrasta com a exuberante decoração barroca do interior. Monumento Nacional ( 2002) classificado.
reviews/4/text:
Si tratta di una piccola chiesa barocca risalente al XVII secolo e voluta dai frati francescani che si insediarono ad Aveiro intorno al 1524.

Alla facciata esterna austera e semplice, si contrappone un interno pregevole con cappelle barocche di un certo spessore artistico, le belle mattonelle del XVIII secolo che provengono da Coimbra e la bella pala d’altare (XVIII secolo) custodita nella cappella maggiore.

Vicina ad un parco e distante alcuni minuti a piedi dal centro storico e dalla cattedrale, è meno nota e visitata anche dai turisti, ma a mio avviso è la chiesa più interessante della città!
reviews/4/title: La chiesa più interessante della città
reviews/5/text: Mais uma igreja de Aveiro bonita e linda como todas as outras,esta também ela bonita,mas um pouco escondida dos circuitos normais,apesar de estar junto ao parque.Recomendo.
reviews/6/text: Eu e meu marido encontramos esta igreja e foi um dos melhores lugares que conhecemos em Aveiro. Agradecemos a senhora voluntária que  nos fez uma descrição sucinta e muito apaixonada deste belo monumento. Vale a pena a visita e agradeço de coração!
reviews/7/text: Nos dimos de cara con ella al pasear por el Parque Infante Don Pedro. Es mas bonita e interesante que la catedral.
reviews/8/text: Vale a pena a visita. Nao e extensa mas a igreja ë uma graca. Com detalhes barroco, muito bonita por dentro.
reviews/9/text: Por casualidade, entrei nesta capela e tive a sorte de ter como cicerone o senhor Henrique Lima, que nos fez uma descrição sucinta e muito apaixonada deste belo monumento. Vale a pena a visita e agradeço ao senhor Henrique Lima a disponibilidade e simpatia com que nos recebeu. Bem haja.
reviews/10/text: Esta igreja de tendencia barroca apresenta uma fachada austera que se contrapõe a riqueza dos azulejos e das talhas do seu interior. Igreja convento construída nos idos 1500 pelos frades franciscanos.
reviews/10/title: Uma igreja que inspira muita paz
reviews/11/text: Se tiver a sorte de conseguir que esteja aberta, entre e delicie-se com a sua beleza de frescos e arquitectónica.
reviews/11/title: Vale a pena, mas costuma estar fechada
reviews/12/text:
Duas pequenas igrejas lindíssimas lado a lado! Bem conservadas, sempre limpas e cheias de luz. Também com museu para visitar.
E foi aqui que tudo começou naquele dia... ;)
reviews/13/text: La descubrimos al pasear por el Parque Infante D. Pedro, fundado por los monjes franciscanos en 1524 es típica del barroco portugués con sus tallas y azulejos

reviews/0/text: Very interesting small museum in a gorgeous Art Nouveau house right on one of the city canals.   The museum also has a very nice cafe in the outside courtyard.
reviews/0/title: Interesting museum to see while visiting Aveiro
reviews/1/text: We visited this museum on September 30th. You can buy a combi ticket for this musuem, the musuem ciadad and the Aveiro museum. If you are looking for a museum like the one in Nancy you will be disappointed. There is no furniture just some information about Art Nouveau and the use of flora in architecture. Unfortunately everything is in Portuguese. The movie on the 2nd floor is in English
reviews/2/text: Some nice things to look at, but it leaves you wanting more. Does not do a good job of explaining the development of the style in Aveiro, and where to see it. There is a computer screens that tries to do this but functions poorly.
reviews/2/title: Only go if you have time to kill
reviews/3/text: This is a delightful house built in the Art Nouveau style at a time when there was a lot of such building going on. Really worthwhile for the facade, the doors and windows inside the first floor, the wonderful tiles, and the gorgeous courtyard, not least the paving in it but also the fountain.
reviews/4/text:
To visit this “Museu Arte Nova de Aveiro”, put the car into the underground car-park of the “Forum, cross the bridge with the statues, and go left, this museum is at about 100 meters from the bridge, so located in one of the most emblematic properties.
More than restoring the ornamental environment of an Art Nouveau house, this museum group treats Art Nouveau as a didactic argument, before ending the visit, you can go to the down floor for a short or long visit of the 
tea house, at night it becomes one of the liveliest bars in the city, with live music on weekends.
reviews/5/text: I am very found of several artists from this era and was dispointed by how little material was actually in the building. Much of it was modern displays or slide shows.
reviews/5/title: Not many original pieces and the top floor not art Nouveau
reviews/6/text: A small permanent collection in a beautiful building- definitely worth a visit. The café at the back is very chilled out 8n the afternoon.
reviews/7/text:
Beautiful Building. The Portuguese certainly knew & still know the art of decorating a building. Compare the austere Germanic approach; depressing!
This is the loveliest building we saw, second to the Railway Station, in Aveiro.
Pity it was closed.
reviews/8/text: Aveiro's "Museu Arte Nova" is located at an iconic building - the "Casa do Major Pessoa" - facing the main canal of the "Ría de Aveiro". The "Art Noveau" construction is kept magnificently and is, indeed, extremely beautiful! Inside, not much to see: permanent and temporary exhibitions on its main subject - "Art Nouveau", plus a road map for a walking tour of some 28 other important "Art Nouveau" buildings in its vicinities. On the ground floor, in the rear patio, a "Tea House" completes the scene. Enjoy!
reviews/8/title: Art Noveau facade in romantic Aveiro!
reviews/9/text: I loved this museum as much for the building that it is in as for the (small) display. There is a film that is worth sitting through which puts the exhibition into historical context. There is also a great little cafe that serves a wide selection of tea and cake.
reviews/10/text:
Excellent museum with several great pieces! The building in itself reflects the "Arte Nova" style, and you can even see more buildings like it through the town. If you are in Aveiro you won't regret visiting it!

Museu excelente com várias grandes peças! O edifício em si reflete o estilo "Arte Nova", e até se pode ver mais edifícios como este pela cidade. Se está em Aveiro não se vai arrepender!
reviews/11/text:
Came on train from Porto for the day to see the Art Noveau. Museum is completely closed with no notices to say when it reopens either on the building or website (which doesn't even say that it's closed!). Google maps also implies that it is open by giving opening times!

It will presumably reopen at some point but don't know how you can check if it is open before travelling.

Building looks fab from the outside so hopefully the work will be finished soon. Rating is because a simple update on the website and a sign outside would be helpful.
reviews/12/text: Loved this place - tables scattered around the courtyard of an art nouveau style house, where as the sun sets they projected old black and white films on the walls and a chap played rather good saxophone to accompany our meal.  NB the museum is closed in the evening, so you have to access the bar around the back, from the fish market entrance.  Its worth it though, a really nice laid back place for a drink.
reviews/12/title: Quirky, classy place to while away an evening
reviews/13/text: The building is a wonderful example of Art Nouveau, however there are almost no exhibits on show. One can watch a short film about the period and that's about it.
reviews/14/text: This is a curious tiny museum housed in the former residence of a local wealthy man who lived in many foreign countries and was a remarkable collector. The museum occupies the whole house, having miscelaneous contents but related to that Art Nouveau era, plus a small auditorium were videos are shown and a nice cafeteria in the back yard. The house has a graceful façade, being the house more remarkable than its contents, in my opinion at least. Tickets are cheap -the facilities are quite small- and combined with the Municipal Museum. One remarkable point is that this museum is located in an area dotted with many Art Nouveau buildings. As most of them are private houses, they aren´t really monumental, but cute of course they are, so the area deserves a pleasant stroll and some fotos, as it´s attractive for those who are into this type of art .
reviews/14/title: Nice place to go if you are visiting the city
reviews/15/text: The service is not so good, the cakes were not fresh at all, and it's all a bit pricey. It's a pity as the house is truly beautiful.
reviews/16/text: Being a big fun of Art Nouveau I was looking forward to this. Was expecting to see all things Art Nouveau but sadly the only highlight was a poor quality video. I was expecting to see furniture and wonder delights of the movement. None to be had. In fact the building is pretty empty.
reviews/17/text:
Well worth going for a peek inside as much of it is still intact.  Be sure to look at both front and back too.
Wrinklies get in gratis.
reviews/18/text:
The Museu de Arte Nova presents a special perspective about  architecture and art 
 novo. The coffee shop bellow is placed in one of the most attractive buildings in Aveiro. do not miss the photo opp :-)
reviews/18/title: Small museum in a beautiful building
reviews/19/text:
It's a picturesque art nouveau house right by one of the canals in Aveiro and its façade draws your attention straight away.
The owners had an idea to make money and there's nothing wrong with it: call it a museum and charge 2 euros!
On the ground floor there's a nice café at day time and bar at night, also with a backdoor entrance.
Then the so-called museum on the other floors but it's nothing but a couple of nicely displayed items with elementary explanation, no depth or content at all.
Go have a coffee and eat a slice of cake, you can skip the 'museum'!
reviews/19/title: Nice but it is not really a musuem!

reviews/4/text: The oldest across the Aveiro River, very nice preserved...great for a kiss...and a selfie with your love one at the sunset!!MUST DO IT for luck!!
reviews/5/text:
A lovely decorative bridge over the canal near the fishermen quarter of the city. You will pass under it if you do the canal cruise.
Dubbed the original lovers bridge in the town, it has retained its charm but the lovers have moved to the ribbon festooned bridge near the Forum.
reviews/6/text: Πρόκειται για μια πεζογέφυρα που ενώνει τις δύο πλευρές του καναλιού São Roque. Έχει κατασκευαστεί το 1952 και το ιδιαίτερο σχήμα της την κάνει να ξεχωρίζει από τις υπόλοιπες γέφυρες του Aveiro. Αν κάνετε "κρουαζιέρα" στα κανάλια με τις χαρακτηριστικές βάρκες moliceiro, είναι βέβαιο ότι θα περάσετε από κάτω. Υπήρξε για χρόνια το βασικό πέρασμα των εργατών που δούλευαν καθημερινά στις αλυκές. Οι κάτοικοι την λένε και γέφυρα των ερωτευμένων, ίσως γιατί προσφέρει προνομιακή θέα προς το ηλιοβασίλεμα πάνω από τις αλυκές του Aveiro.
reviews/7/text: Lo vedrai di sicuro se visiti Aveiro, ma è solo un brutto ponte, niente di più. In generale, Aveiro non ha molto da vedere.
reviews/8/text: A Ponte dos Carcavelos também é conhecida como Ponte dos Namorados. Quem faz o passeio de moliceiro, pela Ria de Aveiro, certamente passará sob ela. A arquitetura é diferenciada das demais. Linda!
reviews/9/text: Na viagem de moliceiro ou mercantel, não esquecer de dar um beijo quando se passa debaixo da ponte! :)
reviews/10/text: A origem do nome. As salinas de Aveiro têm uma longa tradição, e ao longo dos tempos foram sendo propriedade de senhores da zona de Lisboa. Como homenagem às suas terras de origem, tinham por costume colocar nomes de terras de zonas de Lisboa às suas marinhas de sal. Da mesma forma esta ponte recebeu o nome de Carcavelos. A antiga Ponte dos Carcavelos sobre o Canal de S. Roque em Aveiro, era simples, rudimentar e pouco sólida. A atual Ponte dos Carcavelos, também conhecida por ponte dos Namorados, é uma das muitas pontes de bela arquitetura que pode apreciar na Ria de Aveiro. Existem 3 boas formas de visitar a ponte dos Carcavelos. Uma é passeando a pé no parque de São Roque. Também o pode fazer a pé, passeando pelo tradicional bairro da Beira Mar . A outra forma é fazer o passeio de moliceiro, e assim percorrerá também os outros canais da cidade.
reviews/11/text:
Era el punto de unión entre las salinas ylos antiguos almacenes de sal, inicialmente era un puente de madera que fue sustituido por el actual.
Merece la pena recorrer el canal y visitarlo.
reviews/12/text: Ponte pedonale da immortalare nelle foto ricordo in una gita ad Aveiro. Nel canale passano i 'moliceiros', le tradizionali imbarcazioni variopinte che assomigliano un po' alle gondole veneziane.
reviews/13/text: Questo piccolo ponte si trova sul Canale di São Roque, in una zona più lontana rispetto al canale centrale.
reviews/14/text: Esta ponte é uma das muitas que ajudam a atravessar os canais da ria de Aveiro, é linda e possui uma arquitectura fantástica.
reviews/15/text:
Anche questo ponte, s'incontra durante la "gita" nei canali di Aveiro, nel quartiere dei pescatori.
Carino, ma niente di più.
reviews/16/text:
Sendo a ponte mais importante de Aveiro, passar pela mesma de barco ou a pé e obrigatório a visita por ser um monumento histórico.
Recomendo
reviews/16/title: A ponte mais antiga e importante de Aveiro
reviews/17/text: Ponte que permite passar de um lado para o outro do canal de São Roque, Um dos mais antigos da ria. Está em perfeito estado e tem uma águia verde no cimo!!!
reviews/18/text: Petit pont enjambant un canal.  Bien décoré et facile à traverser. Situé dans la partie ouest des canaux.
reviews/19/text: Carino ma niente di eccezionale anche se la cittadina di Aveiro ha tante altre cose da offrire. Vale comunque fare un passaggio sul ponte, se non altro per una foto ricordo.

reviews/0/text: This is a nice place to buy delicious fruit and some local pastry! It’s not a big market, but its nice.

reviews/1/text: O Mercado Manuel Firmino é um espaço único, cheio de vida, aromas e cores. Vale mesmo a pena visitar,
reviews/2/text: Notre promenade le long du canal do Côjo (celui reliant le canal central depuis la Praça Humberto Delgado au lagon bordant le Cais da Fonte Nova) nous a conduit à ce beau marché fermier (immense structure très éclairée) situé en bordure du canal longeant l’Avenida Doutor Lourenço Peixinho. Nous y sommes entrés pour voir de quoi il en retourne. Plusieurs étals étaient inoccupés et le marché était très peu achalandé en ce mardi après-midi de la fin de septembre. On y trouve des produits alimentaires (fruits, légumes, viandes, produits régionaux). Le Mercado Manuel Firmino existe à Aveiro depuis 1899. Il occupait autrefois un bâtiment fait d’une structure métallique achetée de la ville de Porto et était situé dans une zone occupée par les entrepôts d’Aveiro ( ?) avant de déménager dans les nouvelles installations actuelles. Sans aucun doute plus achalandé le samedi.
reviews/2/title: Très beau marché fermier mais peu achalandé le mardi après-midi
reviews/3/text: フォーラムアヴェイロから駅方面に３分くらいのところにある地元の人向けの市場です。平屋建てですが、規模は大きいです。生鮮食品、花などが売っています。
reviews/4/text: É um mercado com espaço próprio e coberto situado no centro de Aveiro, junto à Ria e quase em frente ao Fórum. Espaço, esse, dedicado à venda de variados produtos, dos quais dou destaque, às flores, frutas e legumes.
reviews/5/text: Pues a mí no me gustó nada, es un mercado moderno con sus puestos y sus cosas. Nada del otro mundo. No es el mercado Peixe
reviews/6/text: Petit marché sympa, attention à ne pas arriver après  midi sinon vous ne trouverez que 2 etales de fruits
reviews/7/text: フォルム・ショピングモール近くにあるメルカードです。新鮮な野菜、新鮮な魚がならんでいます。海に面したメルカードは大好きです。魚種が多く新鮮である理由です。
reviews/7/title: メールカードは午前に行くべし
reviews/8/text:
Bem organizado, com bons acessos, proximidade do centro da cidade e muita luz natural, ao Mercado Manuel Firmino falta apenas o comércio de pescado que está noutro ponto da cidade, mais perto da ria.
É um ponto turístico de passagem obrigatória.
reviews/9/text: Mercado muito bem organizado e limpo onde podemos comprar verduras, legumes e todos os tipos de carne mas também podemos saborear bons cafés e refeições cponfeccionadas no próprio local.
reviews/9/title: Conhecendo a cidade de Aveiro em Portugal e seus principais pontos turísticos
reviews/10/text: De beaux fruits et légumes à prix très attractifs. Et surtout dans le marché une cantine O Ramiro : repas complet , un beau plat de morue , verre de vin , café  le tout 6,70 € et un serveur d'une gentillesse exceptionnelle.
reviews/11/text:
Si tratta di un piccolo mercato con banchi (molti purtroppo chiusi, forse perché stagione bassa o per la crisi) di frutta e verdura e poco altro.

Ricorda molto i mercati dei paesini italiani ed europei di decenni fa…per intenderci nulla a che vedere con quelli vasti e "ricchi" del nord Europa o delle grandi città italiane.

Abbiamo comprato delle buona frutta e fatto una passeggiata perché avevamo tempo, ma non è né un’attrazione classica, né un luogo imperdibile….

Piuttosto andate a curiosare il mercato del pesce (in Largo da Praca do Peixe).

N.B.: per chi fosse interessato il mercato si svolge dal lunedì al sabato (o almeno questa è l'informazione ricevuta)
reviews/11/title: Un piccolo mercato di frutta e verdura...
reviews/12/text: Não vi nada de mais nesse mercado, nenhuma arquitetura diferenciada ou destacável, nenhuma história interessante e ainda por cima, vários quiosques estavam vazios (talvez por ser fora de temporada...)
reviews/13/text: Bom mercado ,numa zona central da cidade de Aveiro,e com variedade de produtos á disposição dos clentes.
reviews/14/text: Aqui vi uma coisa muito interessante. De um lado as bancas de um mercado de frutas, verduras, legumes e do outro lado uma feira de livros.
reviews/14/title: Um mercado diferente na visão de uma brasileira
reviews/15/text: Fomos conhecer num domingo a tarde e estava fechado - o que é bem normal em mercados - mas conseguimos observar e ver que é amplo, bem iluminado e com bastante espaço para comercializar.
reviews/15/title: Conhecendo a cidade de Aveiro e suas belezas naturais e gastronômicas.
reviews/16/text: Um mercado bem conceituado no centro da cidade, legumes fresco, peixe fresco e tem muitas barracas de doces típicos. Tem cafés à volta. Muito limpo e organizado.
reviews/17/text:
Fomos já com alguns lugares fechando, mas, o mercado é bem organizado e limpo. Várias bancas com muitos doces e pães típicos, inclusive os tão famosos ovos moles. São artesanais, maiores que os encontrados nas docerias,  e muito saborosos!
Fomos na banca de uma senhora muito alegre e gentil, que nos deu vários doces para provarmos e nos apresentou a morcela de amêndoas. Uma espécie de enchido feito com pasta de amêndoas, açucar e canela, que comemos cortando as fatias, como um chouriço. Bem gostoso!
reviews/18/text: Mercado situado cerca del centro de Aveiro y a un paso del centro comercial Forum Aveiro. Es un mercado moderno, con algunas tiendas de recuerdos en el exterior y con puestos de pescado, carne y flores sobre todo en el interior. Para dar un paseo cerca de los canales
reviews/19/text: É possivel comprar todo o tipo de legumes frescos a bons preços. O mercado foi recuperado há alguns anos, possuindo outro tipo de comércio e restauração nas lojas existentes.

reviews/10/text: Located in a tile covered building, the Welcome Center is staffed by knowledgable people who directed us to the sites of Aveiro. The Art Neuvo buildings and the historical sites.
reviews/10/title: First Stop To the Best of Aveiro
reviews/11/text: in center of town across from park. Very few English language items and map is not too helpful. Luckily always go downhill and you will run into a canal so you cannot get lost.
reviews/12/text: Το Γραφείο Τουρισμού του Aveiro, βρίσκεται δίπλα στο κεντρικό κανάλι της πόλης. Στεγάζεται σε ένα πολύ όμορφο Art Nouveau κτήριο, ενώ περιβάλλεται από άλλα κτήρια της ίδιας αρχιτεκτονικής. Ακόμη και να μην επιθυμείς να αναζητήσεις τουριστικές πληροφορίες για το Aveiro και την ευρύτερη περιοχή, αξίζει να θαυμάσεις τα αρχιτεκτονικά ενδιαφέροντα κτήρια και να τα φωτογραφήσεις. Πάντως, αν χρειαστείτε πληροφορίες για την επίσκεψή σας στην πόλη, το ευγενικό προσωπικό του Γραφείου Τουρισμού θα σας δώσει χρήσιμες πληροφορίες και θα σας προμηθεύσει με δωρεάν χάρτες για να διευκολύνει την επίσκεψή σας.

Aussitôt arrivés au comptoir pas achalandé, on vous remet quelques dépliants et carte de la ville sans vous saluer ni prendre le temps de vous écouter, comme si on voulait se débarasser de vous le plus rapidement possible et qu'on savait à l'avance ce que nous allions demander. Départ de Porto depuis la gare de sao bento
1 h de trajet

Le long du canal ,j ai pris le bus direction Costa Nova ,30 minutes de trajet,bus toutes les heures.

Bref oubliez Aveiro !! Je suis sûre que il y a beaucoup mieux a faire !!! J aurais aimé le savoir. Il n' y a pas grand chose a faire ,a voir et tout est très triste .

reviews/4/text:
Fiquei a conhecer “a fábrica” através da escola do meu filho (seria a visita de estudo de final de ano, se não tivesse aparecido a COVID-19.)
Achei  que seria uma visita muito interessante (como por norma são as visitas aos centros ciência viva).
A visita à Fábrica neste momento está mais pobre do que habitualmente, por culpa das contingências atuais (não tem a exposição permanente, porque era interativa/manipulative e está mais limitada nos workshops que apresenta pelas restrições de distanciamento e higienização de espaços e materiais, mas ainda assim acho que vale a pena!
Em visita a Aveiro, fomos lá com os miúdos fazer dois ateliês - construir e programar um robot de Lego e  cozinha com ciência -elaboração de gelado.
Os miúdos adoraram e já pediram várias vezes para voltar.
Os monitores são divertidos e têm jeito para apresentar a “ciência das coisas” aos miúdos.
Apesar das dificuldades atuais a Fábrica está a tentar reinventar-se e criar novas experiências que sejam viáveis nas exigências do contexto atual.
Neste momento, antes de fazer uma visita, aconselho a ligar previamente para se informar das atividades disponíveis e respetivos horários.
Aproveito para dizer que (especialmente para quem gosta deste tipo de visitas, existe o cartão circuitos ciência viva (ronda is 40-50€) que permite a entrada em todos os centros ciência viva e descontos em parceiros como museus, restaurantes, alojamento...) durante 1 ano e é para o casal ou casal e filhos. Torna-se vantajoso para quem tem centros destes relativamente próximos e quer explorar as suas potencialidades com os miúdos.
Resumidamente recomendo a visita!
reviews/5/text: Talleres interactivos para los mas pequeños y no tan pequeños, nada que ver con un museo, los peques lo pasaran genial visitando alguno de los talleres y descubriendo con sus manos como funcionan las cosas, 100% recomendable si vas con niños.

reviews/1/text: Το ενδιαφέρον αυτό άγαλμα της Santa Joana είναι τοποθετημένο απέναντι από το Μουσείο του Aveiro, ώστε να αντικρίζει τον Καθεδρικό της πόλης. Η πριγκίπισα Santa Joana (1452-1490), έζησε, μόνασε και πέθανε στο μοναστήρι το οποίο σήμερα στεγάζει το Μουσείο της πόλης, όπου και φυλάσσονται τα λείψανά της. Μετά το θάνατό της αγιοποιήθηκε, ενώ έχει ανακηρυχτεί από το 1965 προστάτιδα αγία του Aveiro. Το άγαλμα είναι φιλοτεχνημένο από το γλύπτη Helder Bandarra, ο οποίος γεννήθηκε στην πόλη του Aveiro. Αρχικά, είχε τοποθετηθεί σε άλλο σημείο της πόλης από το 1987, για να μεταφερθεί στη σημερινή του θέση το 2001. Είναι κατασκευασμένο από χαλκό, έχει ύψος τέσσερα μέτρα και στηρίζεται σε βάση από ασβεστόλιθο. Στη μπροστινή πλευρά της βάσης εμφανίζεται το οικόσημο της Santa Joana, με την επιγραφή "Princesa Santa Joana/ Padroeira de Aveiro/ 1452-1490".
reviews/2/text: A estátua em homenagem à Princesa Santa Joana está localizada na Praça do Milenário. Feita em bronze, está de frente para a Sé de Aveiro, pois é a padroeira da cidade.
reviews/3/text: La princesse Joana (1452-1490) était le deuxième enfant d’Alphonse V (1432-1481), roi du Portugal et des Algarves. Son titre de princesse lui a été conféré à la mort hâtive de son frère aîné Jean. Elle a d’ailleurs joué le rôle de régente en 1471 quand son père participa à une expédition militaire à Tanger. Elle retourna toutefois au statut d’Infantes à la naissance de son frère cadet Jean II, le futur roi du Portugal mais la population portugaise continua de l’appeler « Princesse Joana ». Après avoir refusé plusieurs offres de mariage, elle entra au couvent des dominicaines d’Aveiro où elle mena une vie de sainteté. Elle a été béatifiée par le pape Innocent XII en 1693 ce qui fit du couvent de Jésus (Convento de Jesus) un symbole fort du patrimoine religieux portugais. Bien qu'elle n'ait pas été canonisée, elle est connue au Portugal sous le nom de « Princesa Santa Joana ». Sa statue de bronze est située au centre de l’avenue qui porte son nom (Av. Santa Joana) juste en face du couvent de Jesus qui abrite depuis 1911 le très beau musée d’Aveiro et de la cathédrale Se d’Aveiro.

reviews/4/text: Esta estátua em bronze, da Princesa Santa Joana, da autoria do escultor Aveirense Hélder Bandarra, está em perfeita sintonia no espaço físico. reviews/1/text: Marcamos uma visita guiada às salinas, o guia ( um dos trabalhadores da salina) muito gentil e simpático, e com verdadeiro conhecimento do que nos falava. Ficamos muito satisfeitos com a explicação e visita (apesar de estarmos numa altura em que não há sal nas salinas).
reviews/2/text: Η σημερινή Marinha da Noeirinha έχει πάνω από 200 χρόνια ιστορίας. Περιοχή μεταξύ της πόλης του Aveiro και του Ατλαντικού, η οποία αποτελεί παραδοσιακά τόπο παραγωγής αλατιού. Οι αλυκές της Marinha da Noeirinha φημίζονται για το υψηλής ποιότητας αλάτι, ήδη από το 959, οπότε και εμφανίζεται η πρώτη ιστορικά καταγραφή παραγωγής αλατιού στο Aveiro. Ακόμη σήμερα, η παραγωγή αλατιού γίνεται με τον παραδοσιακό χειρωνακτικό τρόπο, ενώ πολλά εργαλεία που χρησιμοποιούνται αποτελούν πιστά αντίγραφα εργαλείων που χρησιμοποιούσαν ανέκαθεν οι εργάτες αλατιού. Διοργανώνονται και επισκέψεις περιήγησης για όποιον ενδιαφέρεται να γνωρίσει από κοντά αυτή την υπερχιλιετή παράδοση αλατοπαραγωγής.

reviews/0/text:
Some have lost their roofs and wooden flooring, but these traditional schist buildings still cling to the steep hillside in a valley of the Serra da Freita, in Portugal’s Magical Mountains. Viewed from a distance, the small village almost looks like it has been hewn out of the mountain rock. The small whitewashed church stands in stark contrast to the rest of the village, that was constructed from the earthy brown metamorphic rock found in this region.

The last residents abandoned Drave in 2009, likely seeking a more comfortable existence elsewhere. The village had no electricity, sanitation, running water, telephone service or mail service, so the residents were truly ‘living off the grid’ before it was seen as a trendy alternative lifestyle. But the location appealed to the Boy Scouts organisation, which uses the village as a base camp. Several of the buildings are now used for camping – by scouts as well as hikers who are passing through. A toilet facility has even been constructed a short distance from the village and water can be collected from the stream that passes nearby.

Now referred to as Aldeia Mágica (Magic Village), Drave is on the tourist map for hikers. Hiking trail PR14 connects Drave to the village of Regoufe, about 4km away. Several websites claim that the trail from Regoufe is the only way to reach Drave. One could be forgiven for thinking that they are conspiring to keep non-hikers away from the village, because I discovered that there is, in fact, an easier way to visit Drave. You can drive there!

When I was planning a route to Regoufe, for the hike to Drave, my GPS navigator showed a road that went directly to Drave. Past experience has taught me that ‘roads’ on a map can be rough trails that are difficult to ride, but it was worth exploring. I plotted a direct route to Drave, but was prepared to detour to Regoufe, if necessary, and hike in.

The 94km between Porto and Drave can be covered in 1 hour 45 minutes. The first segment of the route uses the A1 and A32 motorways but nicer riding-roads begin after leaving the motorways and joining the N224-1. Before long, I was on narrow mountain roads enjoying gorgeous scenery. I love riding in the Magical Mountains – one of my favourite places to ride.

The narrow road to Drave is off Estrada EN1123, after passing through the village of Coelheira. It is a dirt and gravel road, advertised by white paint markings on an adjacent wall for Drave and Gourim. The track has some steep hills as it begins its descent towards Drave. Part way along the track there is a stone marker at a Y-junction. Left for Gourim and straight on for Drave. The track is only wide enough for one car to pass. As it gets closer to Drave, the descent gets steeper with several hairpin turns. I’d made the right decision to take my BMW adventure bike, as it is much better suited for the terrain than my Honda CBF. But several standard two-wheel drive cars had made the journey along the track and had parked in a couple of places towards the end. Whilst not advertised online, local residents are well aware of this route, and had driven out to enjoy their Sunday afternoon. The dirt road eventually narrows to a single footpath that is steeper and more rugged than the road. It is too narrow for cars and too rugged for most motorcycles. So vehicles are parked and the last 10-15 minutes must be covered on foot.

The village is split into two sections, on different hills with the mountain stream running between them. Whilst the smaller part is mostly derelict, it does have one intact building that is used for camping with an adjacent area that can be used for cooking and socialising. In fact, at the time of my visit, a group of teenagers had set up a temporary camp there. The main section of the village has more buildings, with more that are available for camping. Most of the buildings can be explored – those ready for campers are not locked but have wooden doors that can be closed. The whitewashed church is locked and inaccessible. The shape and size of some of the buildings suggest that they were used to house animals (goats, perhaps) or were for general storage.

The layout of the village was dictated by the landscape, so buildings have different shapes and are loosely assembled at different heights and different angles, with narrow walkways between them. It’s an interesting place to explore and to imagine what life was like for its previous inhabitants. I was particularly impressed by the footpaths through the village, that were constructed using large slabs of rock.

I visited on a Sunday afternoon in August, so there were more local visitors than might be expected on a weekday. Yet, there weren’t many people wandering around the village buildings. Most of the visitors (about 20) were congregated around a beautiful, shaded pool that is fed by a cascading mountain stream. Picnicking, sunbathing and generally enjoying a peaceful afternoon in the mountains. The temperature in Drave was about 28C (82F). Hot, but still a bit cooler than the 36C (96.8F) temperatures down at lower elevations. I relaxed by the pool for a while to eat a snack and have a drink, before continuing to explore the village.

I spent an hour exploring the village before heading back up the hill to my motorcycle for the ride back to Porto. A visit to Drave could be combined with visits to some of the other attractions in Serra da Freita.

reviews/0/text: Interesting old building that now seems to be an exhibition space. It contained an art exhibition when I visited. It also contained maps highlighting special interests so I got the Art Nouveau one (there were other topics)
reviews/1/text: The best thing to do to visit this and other location in walking distance is to leave your car into the underground and paying car park of the “Forum”, the “Capitania” is located on a privileged location on the Côjo Channel, in its original function, the building was a tidal mill, having been built in the 15th century, a time to which the arches supported on stilts over the waters of the channel. A few centuries later, around 1830, it would become a support building for the porcelain factory of José Ferreira Pinto Basto, founder of the renowned Vista Alegre. In 1903, Francisco Augusto da Silva Rocha renovated the building along the route that still remains today. And it was also the residence of the port captain, until 1992, the year of the construction of the new Port of Aveiro in Gafanha da Nazaré, and actually is serves as a gallery dedicated to temporary exhibitions.

Μετά το 1992 όμως, το λιμάνι του Aveiro μεταφέρθηκε στη Gafanha da Nazaré και το κτήριο περιήλθε στα χέρια του Δήμου. reviews/0/text: Cette statue de bronze reposant sur un piédestal en pierre occupe le centre de la Praça da Republica à Aveiro (ancien site de l’église dédiée à saint Michel, détruite en 1835), en face de l’hôtel de Ville (Câmara Municipal) construit à la fin du XVIIIe siècle et de l’Igreja da Misericordia construite entre 1600 et 1669. Cette statue a été élevée sur cette place en 1889 pour rendre hommage à José Estêvão Coelho de Magalhães (1809-1862), natif d’Aveiro, qui fut journaliste, homme politique (licence en droit de l'Université de Coimbra) et orateur de renom. Il faisait partie de l’opposition de gauche à la Chambre des représentants. En tant que représentant politique, il obtint du gouvernement la construction à Aveiro d’un lycée (construit entre 1855 et 1860 à l’ouest de la Praça da Republica) ainsi que le passage par Aveiro de la voie ferroviaire reliant Lisbonne à Porto. C’est aussi lui qui fonda en 1841 « The September Revolution », un journal influent de la presse libérale. Prônant des solutions plus radicales que celles préconisées par les partis politiques de l'époque, José Estêvão a été souvent contraint à chercher refuge à l'étranger (en Angleterre et sur l'île de Terceira). Sur le plan militaire, il a participé au débarquement de Mindelo (épisode de la guerre civile portugaise de 1828-1834) ainsi qu’à la guerre de Patuleia (guerre civile au Portugal entre 1846 et 1847) en intégrant l'armée rebelle qui opérait dans l'Alentejo. La statue a été réalisée à Lisbonne par le sculpteur portugais José Simões de Almeida Júnior (1844-1926).
